article.p: See the example in README.md, eg.R, eg2.R and eg3.R and the code in getType.R.

section.title: Getting Type Information from Code
section.para:
We look at the influence.c file in the stats package in the base R code. This has one routine named influence which is invoked from R code via the .Call mechanism. We are interested in programmatically determining what it returns. In fact, it returns a list with either 3 or 4 elements. In the case of 4 elements, these are named hat, coefficients, sigma, wt.res. If only 3 elements are returned, the coefficients is not included. This is controlled by the second argument do_coef, a scalar logical.
hat is a numeric vector of length n, the number of rows in the QR matrix passed in the first argument to the routine.
coefficients is a matrix with numeric elements and dimension n and k. k is the integer value in the mqr list (first argument) in the element named rank.
sigma is a numeric vector of length n
wt.res is the value passed in the third argument to the routine. It is also passed to the routine lminfl. (Are the values modified in the routine?)

We start by generating the IR from the C code. We do this via a make file. However, here is the command
/Users/duncan/LLVM/LLVM5.0.1/llvm-5.0.1.src/build/bin/clang -I/Users/duncan/R-3.4.4/include -DNDEBUG -I/usr/local/include -fPIC -O2 -S -emit-llvm influence.c -o influence.ir
Note that we need to use the same version of clang as the LLVM libraries we use in Rllvm.

library(Rllvm) m = parseIR("influence.ir")
names(m)
f = m$influence b = getBlocks(f)
There are 17 blocks

We find the return instruction(s):
w = sapply(b, function(x) any(sapply(x[], is, "ReturnInst"))) which(w)
ret = getTerminator(b[[which(w)]])
Alternatively, we can now use
ret = getReturnValues(f)[[1]]
ret[[1]] #llvmDump(ret[[1]])
So this is a call to Rf_protect(). Of course, there is a corresponding call to Rf_unprotect() that takes place later. We are not returning the call to Rf_protect(). LLVM/clang is merely pointing us to the place where the return value was initially created. It is populated in code that is run before the return.
So we get the "code" for the object being protected
ret[[1]][[1]] #llvmDump(ret[[1]][[1]])
This is a call to Rf_allocVector. We are now back in familiar territory (as in )
We look at the first argument in the call to Rf_allocVector to find the type of the R object:
ans = ret[[1]] getValue(ans[[1]])
This returns 19 corresponding to VECSXP in Rinternals.h. (This is a regular/generic list.)
The number of elements is in the second element of ans
ans[[2]]
This is a SelectInst
llvmDump(ans[[2]])
%conv30 = select i1 %tobool29, i64 3, i64 4
Depending on the condition, the number of elements is either 3 or 4. We can get these values with
sapply(ans[[2]][2:3], getValue)
since they are literal constants in this case. If they were computations, we'd have to follow their contents.
The condition in the SelectInst
ans[[2]][[1]]
[1] " %tobool29 = icmp eq i32 %9, 0"
corresponds to the docoef in the code which comes from the value in the logical scalar passed to the routine as an argument do_coef, i.e.,
int docoef = asLogical(do_coef);
What is interesting about the influence routine is that it inserts named elements into the list it returns and we want to know the types and the names of these elements.

Rather than looking at how the value of ans was created, let's look at the variable ans itself. This was ans[[1]]. We can find where it is used directly and from this we get the users.
usrs = getAllUsers(ret) # [[1]]
We can look at the instructions that use this return value:
sapply(usrs, as, 'character')
ret %struct.SEXPREC* %call32 %call57 = call %struct.SEXPREC* @SET_VECTOR_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call32, i64 %18, %struct.SEXPREC* %e) #3 %call52 = call %struct.SEXPREC* @SET_VECTOR_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call32, i64 %17, %struct.SEXPREC* %call16) #3 %call46 = call %struct.SEXPREC* @SET_VECTOR_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call32, i64 1, %struct.SEXPREC* %call13) #3 %call39 = call %struct.SEXPREC* @SET_VECTOR_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call32, i64 0, %struct.SEXPREC* %call8) #3 %call37 = call %struct.SEXPREC* @Rf_setAttrib(%struct.SEXPREC* %call32, %struct.SEXPREC* %11, %struct.SEXPREC* %call36) #3

There are 4 calls to SET_VECTOR_ELT, as we expect. One of these is within an if() statement. This is the second call. So the elements of the list will be in a different order/positions if this docoef condition is true or false.

Let's take a look at the 2nd user in our list usrs. This corresponds to the first element to be added to the list. We "know" that this is a call to SET_VECTOR_ELT (but we could check) and that the first argument is the list we are returning. We can query what value is being inserted
v = usrs[[2]] v[[3]]
This is a call to Rf_protect. It corresponds to the value of the local variable hat. We can follow this object
getName(getCalledFunction(v[[3]][[1]]))
to see Rf_allocVector. And then we are back to the familiar and can find the type of R vector/object and the length. The type is 14
getValue(v[[3]][[1]][[1]])
corresponding to a REALSXP.

Here the length is not a constant, but computed:
v[[3]][[1]][[2]]
This is an instruction of class SExtInst. This casts a value to an 64-bit integer. What is the number:
v[[3]][[1]][[2]][[1]]
" %call2 = tail call i32 @Rf_nrows(%struct.SEXPREC* %call) #3"
This is a call to Rf_nrows() What is this being called with, or more importantly, which R object are we getting the number of rows for?
v[[3]][[1]][[2]][[1]][[1]]
[1] " %call = tail call %struct.SEXPREC* @getListElement(%struct.SEXPREC* %mqr, i8* getelementptr inbounds ([3 x i8], [3 x i8]* @.str, i64 0, i64 0)) #3"
So this comes from the call nrows(qr) and qr comes from qr = getListElement(mqr, "qr").

The basics of the following are partially implemented in getType.R (but not the getType function in Rllvm.) It needs more work, but gives the basics.
source("getType.R") r = compReturnType(f) class(r) names(r) r$length r$elNames sapply(r$els, class)

The last instruction in our list of users of the return value sets the names attribute. We can see this with
usrs[[6]]
[1] " %call37 = call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_setAttrib(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call32, %struct.SEXPREC.8* %11, %struct.SEXPREC.8* %call36) #3"
And the second argument to this is the symbol naming the attribute, and
getName(usrs[[6]][[2]][[1]])
gives R_NamesSymbol as the name of the global variable.

In this routine, the third argument to the call to Rf_setAttrib() is a call.
nmsVec = usrs[[6]][[3]]
[1] " %call36 = call %struct.SEXPREC* @Rf_allocVector(i32 16, i64 %conv35) #3"
This allocates the character vector, but doesn't fill it in of course. This comes in other code. So, like the list we are returning, we have to find this call and then which instructions use it to find the names of the elements.

section.title: Finding the Names
section.para:
Let's pursue the names of the returned list to illustrate that it is the same basic process as finding the elements of the list itself.
nu = getAllUsers(nmsVec)
[1] " call void @SET_STRING_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call36, i64 %18, %struct.SEXPREC* %call59) #3" [2] " call void @SET_STRING_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call36, i64 %17, %struct.SEXPREC* %call55) #3" [3] " call void @SET_STRING_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call36, i64 1, %struct.SEXPREC* %call49) #3" [4] " call void @SET_STRING_ELT(%struct.SEXPREC* %call36, i64 0, %struct.SEXPREC* %call42) #3" [5] " %call37 = call %struct.SEXPREC* @Rf_setAttrib(%struct.SEXPREC* %call32, %struct.SEXPREC* %11, %struct.SEXPREC* %call36) #3"
Let's get the IR name of our nmsVec variable:
getName(nmsVec)
This is call36. From the two outputs, we can see that 4 of the calls are to SET_STRING_ELT with call36 (our IR variable) as the first argument. The final use is a call to Rf_setAttrib() and call36 is the final argument. This final use is setting the names on the list to be returned by the routine. We saw this earlier in the uses of the list itself (call32).

As with SET_VECTOR_ELT, the three arguments to SET_STRING_ELT are the vector, the position and the name element. Let's look at the 4th of these calls to SET_STRING_ELT. This corresponds to the first SET_STRING_ELT call for this vector in the C code. We get the position with
getValue(nu[[4]][[2]])
This is the constant 0, i.e., the first element.

Note that two of the calls to SET_STRING_ELT have literal values for the positions - 0 and 1. These are not in the C code. Instead, that uses nm and increments that variable. The second instance of this is within an if() statement. However, the compiler has determined that these are the literal values and inserted them as an optimization step.

What is the value that is being inserted, i.e., the name? This is the third argument. In , we don't just insert the string. We need to create a CHARSXP. So this is a call to Rf_mkChar. Its only argument is the string. In this case, it is a literal value, a ConstantExpr. LLVM stores this in a GlobalVariable within the module.
See findValue() in getType.R Implement getting this. Can use the name of the .str.3 See code in class.R and getType.R and added to Rllvm. Works, but may not be best way to do this. So probably needs some robustifying.
ii = as(cexpr, "Instruction") ii[[1]] # GlobalVariable
getName(ii[[1]])
v = .Call("R_GlobalVariable_getInitializer", ii[[1]])
v is a Constant.
getValue(v) fails 'don't know the class is of the Value" It is "ConstantDataArray"
A different approach gives 4 values, but incorrect values. m[[".str.1", value = TRUE]]
getValue(m[[".str.1"]]) # Now works - June 9
setMethod("show", "Value", function(x) print(as(x,'character')))
#getValue(ii[[1]])
# Operands ii[[2]] ii[[3]]

Let's look at one of the 2 cases for which we don't have a literal value for position. These are the first and second elements in our list of uses. We look at the first and specifically its second argument
nu[[1]][[2]]
This is of class ZExtInst, a cast to an 64-bit integer from a regular 32 bit integer.
" %18 = zext i32 %inc53 to i64"
The value being cast is in the first argument
as(nu[[1]][[2]][[1]], 'character')
We need to get the variable. OverflowingBinaryOperator is just added, but its first element from R is the 1.
bof = nu[[1]][[2]][[1]] getOpcode(bof) # add

Let's look at SET_VECTOR_ELT inside the if() body. This is
i = usrs[[4]]
We can get the block/parent of this with
getParent(i)
We have lost the "if" aspect in the IR that we had in the AST. The "if" is in the name of the block and other labels.

We can find which blocks lead to this block.
a = getPredecessor(getParent(i))
We look at the terminator to see what condition brings us to the body of the if statement in which the SET_VECTOR_ELT occurs.
br = getTerminator(a)
This is a simple branch. We branch to the SET_VECTOR_ELT part if this false. We know this because
identical(getSuccessor(br, 2), getParent(i))
is .

The condition for the branch is
cond = br[[1]]
and looks like
[1] " %tobool43 = icmp eq i32 %12, 0"
This involves the variable named %12 in the IR. We can get this variable by accessing the first element of the condition. This is a LoadInst, so we follow that to get
getName(cond[[1]][[1]])
Here we asked for the name.
getType(cond[[1]][[1]])

section.title: Types of the Elements
section.para:
For the returned list, we find the code that inserts the elements into the list:
w = sapply(usrs, function(x) is(x, "CallInst") && getName(getCalledFunction(x)) == "SET_VECTOR_ELT")
Now we can get the values of the objects being inserted
vals = lapply(usrs[w], `[[`, 3)
[[1]] [1] "%struct.SEXPREC.8* %e"
[[2]] [1] " %call16 = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_protect(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call15) #3"
[[3]] [1] " %call13 = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_protect(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call12.sink) #3"
[[4]] [1] " %call8 = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_protect(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call7) #3"
We can follow these and get their type.

The first of these is just an Argument/parameter, specifically the one named 'e'. We know it is a generic object. We can examine the code to see if we can deduce more specific information, or we can check the code that calls the influence routine. There is a call REAL(e) which indicates it is a numeric vector or matrix. We find all the users of this with
getAllUsers(vals[[1]]) # or m$influence$e
We see only 2 - the insertion into the result and the call to REAL.

The second element of vals is
[1] " %call16 = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_protect(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call15) #3"
We get the argument to Rf_protect and see
" %call15 = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_allocVector(i32 14, i64 %conv) #3"
We pass this to getCallType in getType.R and get back
$type [1] "REALSXP"
$length NULL
attr(,"class") [1] "RVector"
indicating a numeric vector. We don't currently implement the mechanism to get the length for this vector, but we can extend this. It is somewhat involved here. This leads to a call to Rf_nrows(obj) and the obj is the call getListElement(mqr, "qr"). This involves chasing down the "qr" constant (easy enough). But we don't know at compile time to which element of mqr that corresponds. So we can resolve this statically.

The third element potentially inserted into the result is
" %call13 = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_protect(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call12.sink) #3"
Again, we pass this to getCallType.
[[1]] $type [1] "REALSXP"
$length [1] 0
attr(,"class") [1] "RVector"
[[2]] $type [1] "REALSXP"
$dims $dims$nrow NULL
$dims$ncol NULL
attr(,"class") [1] "RMatrix"
We get a list with 2 elements as the result. This is because there are two possible values. One is a numeric vector and the other is a numeric matrix. These two cases come from the fact that coefficients is initialized conditionally. In the first case, we create a vector of length 0 and we captured that. We did not currently get the dimensions for the matrix case.

We can follow the matrix dimensions.
vals[[3]][[1]][[2]][[2]]
" %call2 = tail call i32 @Rf_nrows(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call) #3"
So we are computing the number of rows. When we look at the object, we see
vals[[3]][[1]][[2]][[2]][[1]]
" %call = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @getListElement(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %mqr, i8* getelementptr inbounds ([3 x i8], [3 x i8]* @.str, i64 0, i64 0)) #3"
We are back to the situation we had above with getListElement() with a named element.

Finally, we look at the last of the vals elements
[1] " %call8 = tail call %struct.SEXPREC.8* @Rf_protect(%struct.SEXPREC.8* %call7) #3"
Again, getCallType returns
$type [1] "REALSXP"
$length NULL
attr(,"class") [1] "RVector"
i.e., a numeric vector. Again, the length is related to the getListElement() call.
